etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Frederick Elworthy (1830–1907), philologist and antiquary. From literary + -ism

definitions: A word, phrase, or other use of language that is characteristic of or peculiar to literature or the art of writing, especially of a self-conscious literary type; a literary convention, device, or cliché.

notes.text: Often with implications of pretentiousness or the loss of immediacy of expression.

definitions: The practice of using literary language, references, or conventions, especially at the expense of freshness and clarity of expression; the use of literaryisms; the tendency to use these.
